Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an existing custody or visitation order may be modified when the petitioner demonstrates a material change in circumstances since the entry of the order and that modification is in the best interests of the child(ren). See Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209, § 31; see also cases construing the statute and applying the “material change” and “best interests” standards.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under Massachusetts law to hear and decide petitions to modify custody and visitation orders entered in this Commonwealth. See Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209, § 31; Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208 and the Probate and Family Court jurisdictional provisions.

G.L. c. 209A (emergency protective measu.proposition: See G.L. c. 209A (emergency protective measures) and the Court’s equitable powers to protect child safety.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, \u00a7 51A.proposition: The facts described above (physical grabbing leaving a mark; exposure to violent arguments; neighbor-reported police intervention) raise concerns for the physical and emotional well-being of the minor children and potentially trigger mandated reporting obligations under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, § 51A.

Gallop v. Gallop, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1.relevant_excerpt: The defendant, Bernardo Nadal-Ginard, was indicted on twenty-two counts of larceny of over $250 in violation of G. L. c. 266, § 30… In this appeal, the defendant attacks numerous of the trial judge’s actions, principally the judge’s submitting to the jury… the theory of his alleged larceny by false pretenses… We therefore affirm his convictions.

Finnerty v. Finnerty, 59 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: This opinion concerns establishment of a prescriptive easement and the requirement that such an easement be confined to a particular, defined route. It does not involve domestic relations, visitation, child custody, material change of circumstances, the best interests standard, or judicial authority to impose conditions on visitation for child safety. The case is therefore irrelevant to the family-law proposition for which it is cited.
Finnerty v. Finnerty, 59 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Following a jury-waived trial to establish an easement by prescription, a judge of the Superior Court found that the party claiming the easement, the plaintiff Jeffrey Stone, had not ‘proven any particular location where the prescriptive easement crosses the defendants’ land.’ That finding defeats Stone’s claim because, under the authority of Hoyt v. Kennedy, 170 Mass. 54, 56-57 (1898), a person may not acquire an easement of passage by prescription that is not substantially confined to a regular and particularized route.”

School Comm. of Natick, a teacher-dismissal/collective bargaining case. It concerns procedural and contractual rights in a reduction-in-force context, not custody/visitation, material change of circumstances, or best interests of the child. It also does not discuss the court’s authority to impose conditions on visitation to protect child safety, so it cannot serve as illustrative precedent for that family-law proposition.
F. v. F., 395 Mass. 461 (1985)..relevant_excerpt: “Martin’s principal contention before us is that he was entitled to a ‘meaningful hearing’ under G. L. c. 71, § 42, and under the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment… In Milne v. School Comm. of Manchester, 381 Mass. 581, 582 (1980), we held that the notice and hearing provisions of G. L. c. 71, § 42, do not apply to ‘any dismissal decision based solely on an actual decrease in the number of pupils….’”

B. v. B., 410 Mass. 416 (1991)..proposition: Relevant Massachusetts case law (illustrative precedent recognizing material change of circumstances, the best interests rule, and the Court’s authority to impose conditions on visitation to protect child safety). See, e.g.:
B. v. B., 410 Mass. 416 (1991)..support_reasoning: The cited opinion is a medical malpractice tribunal case (Kopycinski v. Aserkoff), not B. v. B., and it does not address family law concepts such as material change of circumstances, best interests of the child, or judicial authority to impose visitation conditions. Its holdings concern the operation and voting authority of medical malpractice tribunals under G.L. c. 231, § 60B. Therefore, it does not support the proposition cited regarding child custody/visitation standards or court authority to condition visitation for child safety.
B. v. B., 410 Mass. 416 (1991)..relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 231, § 60B (1988 ed.), provides for the screening claims of medical malpractice by a tribunal. The statute states, in part, that "[e]very action for malpractice, error or mistake against a provider of health care shall be heard by a tribunal consisting of a single justice of the superior court, a physician... and an attorney... at which hearing the plaintiff shall present an offer of proof and said tribunal shall determine if the evidence presented if properly substantiated is sufficient to raise a legitimate question of liability appropriate for judicial inquiry or whether the plaintiff's case is merely an unfortunate medical result."

Erb for the probate of an instrument purporting to be the last will of Maud E. Buzzell (decedent)… We hold that there was sufficient evidence to support the judge’s finding of undue influence, and in so holding, do not address the issue of testamentary capacity.”

In re Marriage of Shea, 56 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: In re Marriage of Shea, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 777 (2003).
In re Marriage of Shea, 56 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Relevant Massachusetts case law (illustrative precedent recognizing material change of circumstances, the best interests rule, and the Court’s authority to impose conditions on visitation to protect child safety). See, e.g.:
In re Marriage of Shea, 56 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: This case is a criminal sentencing appeal about improper consideration of uncharged conduct in imposing a prison term. It does not involve family law, material changes of circumstances, child custody or visitation, the best‑interests standard, or judicial authority to impose conditions on visitation to protect child safety. Citing it as Massachusetts case law on those domestic‑relations principles is therefore inaccurate and out of context.
In re Marriage of Shea, 56 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: "Discussion. It is black letter law in the Commonwealth that a defendant cannot be punished for uncharged conduct. See, e.g., Commonwealth v. Goodwin, 414 Mass. 88, 93 (1993). This means a judge may not ‘permit the sentence to vary because she thinks the defendant is guilty of [uncharged] misconduct.’... Punishment is appropriate only for conduct of which the defendant has been charged and convicted."

Casey v. Casey, 27 Mass. The judgments are reversed, and the matter is remanded to the Superior Court for the entry of judgments for the defendants.”

McCarthy v. Tobin, 406 Mass. 144 (1990)..relevant_excerpt: “A sentencing judge is given great discretion in determining a proper sentence… He may consider a wide range of factors in mitigation of the defendant’s guilt, including the defendant’s behavior, family life, and employment… The sentencing hearing is not a static proceeding in which the result is predictable. It is a crucial stage in the system of justice at which the skill and performance of defense counsel can significantly affect the interests of the defendant.”
